intro.title: How did we end up here?
intro.description:
It all starts with a bunch of old photos (and yes, some of them probably should have stayed hidden in the drawers...). You'll find us as kids, with funny faces, awkward poses, and outfits that today would only be trendy... on Mars. Then came the years when we met and, day by day, we began to write our story. The rest? Trips, hugs, crazy moments, and memories that brought us to where we are today. Here we are: a mix of tender, funny, and unforgettable moments.

Explore and... have fun!

chiara_simone_madonna_miracolo.title: The little Roman Lourdes
chiara_simone_madonna_miracolo.description: The altar of Our Lady of the Miracle, in the Basilica of Santâ€™Andrea delle Fratte. A place of prayer, faith, beauty, and meaning, which preserves the memory of an extraordinary event that took place on January 20, 1842: the apparition of the Virgin Mary and the conversion of the young Alphonse Ratisbonne. Today this place is also a fundamental part of our journey of faith, together with the Minims fathers and our consecrated brothers.

intro.title2: Sanctuary of Our Lady of the Miracle
intro.subtitle: A special corner of Rome, between art and spirituality.
intro.description: We are just a stone's throw from Piazza di Spagna, but here, as soon as you step inside, it feels like entering another dimension: silence, art, spirituality. A true hidden gem.

origin.title: Origins and History
origin.p1: The name "delle Fratte" comes from the fact that, once upon a time, this area was full of gardens and brambles.
origin.p2: The church already existed in medieval times, but it was in the 17th century that it was rebuilt by the great architect Borromini, who also designed the beautiful dome and bell tower.

angels.title: The Angels
angels.description1: Among the most striking elements of the church are two angels sculpted by Gian Lorenzo Bernini, originally intended for Ponte Sant'Angelo. Considered too beautiful to remain outdoors, they were brought here to be preserved.
angels.description2: One angel holds the crown of thorns, a symbol of Christ's suffering; the other displays the cartouche with the inscription 'INRI' (IÄ“sus NazarÄ“nus RÄ“x IÅ«daeÅrum), placed on the cross.

miracle.title: The Miracle of the Apparition
miracle.description1: "[...] the whole church darkened, except for a single chapel that radiated with the most vivid brilliance, and I saw on the altar standing alive, tall, majestic, beautiful, and full of mercy, the Most Blessed Virgin Mary [...]
miracle.description2: At this sight, I fell to my knees where I was. [...] I could barely fix my gaze on Mary's hands, and in them I saw the expression of forgiveness and mercy.
miracle.description3: [...] although she said no words to me, I fully understood the horror of the state I was in, the beauty of the Catholic religion, in a word, I understood everything."

ratisbonne.title: The Conversion of Ratisbonne
ratisbonne.description1: On January 20, 1842, a young French Jew named Alphonse Ratisbonne, known for his deep skepticism and anti-Christian stance, entered Sant'Andrea delle Fratte seemingly by chance. He had accepted a friend's dare to wear the Miraculous Medal, but what happened next changed his life forever: at the side altar, he saw the Virgin Mary.
ratisbonne.description2: The experience moved him so profoundly that he converted to Catholicism, became a Jesuit priest, and dedicated his life to spreading the faith. His conversion, recognized as miraculous, became a powerful symbol of Marian devotion in the Church.

medal.subtitle: A symbol of faith, grace and spiritual protection
medal.description1: The Miraculous Medal was given to Alphonse Ratisbonne by his friend, Baron ThÃ©odore de BussiÃ¨res, who challenged him to wear it. This medal originates from the apparitions of the Virgin Mary to Saint Catherine LabourÃ© in 1830. Mary revealed its design and promised great graces to those who would wear it with faith.
medal.description2: On the back are twelve stars, symbolizing Mary's crown, surrounding a large 'M' intertwined with a cross. Below are the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary: one crowned with thorns, the other pierced by a sword.

0.title: Custodians of Sant'Andrea delle Fratte
0.description: The church has been cared for by the Minims since 1585, the year Pope Sixtus V entrusted its administration to them. Since then, the friars have dedicated themselves to prayer and service, faithfully preserving the spiritual and artistic heritage of Sant'Andrea delle Fratte.

1.title: In the Shadow of the Rock
1.description: Francesco was born in 1416 in Paola, a town in Calabria, southern Italy. Devout from a young age and chose to live as a hermit in a cave near his hometown. Embracing solitude, prayer, and extreme poverty, he attracted followers drawn to his radical lifestyle of humility and penance. This would eventually lead to the birth of the Order of Minims.

2.title: A Life of Miracles and Mercy
2.description: San Francesco was known for miraculous acts: healing the sick, multiplying loaves, and even walking on water using his cloak. Among his many wonders, one of the most beloved is the story of Martinello, a little lamb who followed him like a friend. When the lamb was unknowingly slaughtered, cooked, and served by a worker, Francesco wept and prayed and Martinello miraculously returned to life, a tender symbol of his compassion for all creation.

3.title: Living the Mission Today
3.description: The Minims friars who live today at Sant'Andrea delle Fratte embody the spirit of their founder with kindness and joy. Always ready to greet, listen, and guide, they cultivate a welcoming environment through prayer, conversation, and community activities. Their simple yet radiant presence continues to inspire and bring people closer to faith in everyday life.

4.title: Did You Know They Don't Eat Meat?
4.description: The Minims are the only religious order that, in addition to the vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience, observe a fourth vow: "perpetual Lent", which means abstaining from meat and animal products. This choice embodies penance, sobriety, and daily conversionâ€”renouncing excess to place God at the center and walk in solidarity with the poor and suffering.

privacy_policy.title: Privacy Policy
paragraphs: Pursuant to Article 13 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (GDPR), we inform you that the personal data collected through this website will be processed as described below. The data controller is Simone De Cristofaro (email: info@chiaraesimone.it).

Categories of data may include: name, email address, phone number (if provided), and any other information voluntarily entered in the contact form or comments section. Technical data (e.g., IP address, device/browser metadata) may be processed for security and anti-spam purposes (e.g., reCAPTCHA, if enabled).

Purposes of processing:
  • Contact replies: to respond to messages sent via the contact form.
  • Comments & notifications: to publish your comments and, if you opt in, send notifications about new comments related to the same photo or story.
  • Security & anti-spam: to protect the service from abuse and spam (e.g., via reCAPTCHA, if enabled).
  • Site operation: to ensure security and proper functioning of the website.

Legal bases: (a) our legitimate interest in responding to your request (Art. 6(1)(f) GDPR); (b) your consent for publishing comments and sending email notifications, where applicable (Art. 6(1)(a) GDPR); (c) our legitimate interest in ensuring security and preventing abuse (Art. 6(1)(f) GDPR). Where consent is the basis, you may withdraw it at any time without affecting the lawfulness of processing before withdrawal.

Providing data is optional. However, an email address is necessary to reply to your contact request or to send you notifications if you opt in. Without the required data, some features may not be available.

Recipients/Processors: we use trusted service providers for hosting and email delivery (e.g., AWS services primarily within the EU/EEA) and anti-spam (e.g., Google reCAPTCHA, if enabled). These providers process data on our behalf under appropriate data-protection agreements. Please refer to their privacy policies for details.

Data location and transfers: where possible, data are stored within the EU/EEA (e.g., AWS eu-west-1). Some processing (such as email delivery or anti-spam) may involve transfers to countries outside the EU/EEA. In such cases, appropriate safeguards are applied (e.g., Standard Contractual Clauses).

Retention: contact-form data are stored only for the time strictly necessary to handle your request and, in any case, no longer than 6 months from receipt. Comment-related data are stored for as long as the comment remains visible on the site or until you request deletion. Email-subscription data are retained until you unsubscribe.

Your rights: you may request access, rectification, erasure, or restriction of processing of your personal data, object to processing, and (where applicable) withdraw consent. To exercise your rights, write to: info@chiaraesimone.it. You also have the right to lodge a complaint with the Italian Data Protection Authority (Garante).

Cookies and third-party tools: we do not use analytics cookies. If enabled, Google reCAPTCHA may place cookies strictly necessary for security and anti-spam purposes. The emoji picker used on this site (@ctrl/ngx-emoji-mart) runs entirely in your browser and may store recently used emojis or UI preferences in your deviceâ€™s localStorage to improve usability; it does not send your personal data to third parties.

Minors: this website is intended for a general audience. If you are under the age required by applicable law to give valid consent, please obtain consent from a parent or guardian before using interactive features.
